level_1.text: My divorce was finalized this morning. Twenty-three years of marriage, and it all came down to a ten-minute hearing where the judge asked if we'd tried counseling.

wait.text: I walked past our old house on the way here. She's already changed the curtains. Azure-blue with planets on them. Makes no sense - there are no visible planets in daytime.
The only moments of grace came when I was patient and waited for her to fill the air. Every time I opened my mouth, I was stunned by what came out. If only I could have been stunned into silence.

acknowledge.text: It's remarkable, the lengths to which people will go to assert their independence. The curtains are her way of saying I don't exist anymore.

clarify.text: The curtains? They make my blood boil. Not because they're ugly - they're actually tasteful. It's that she chose them without considering my input. After twenty-three years.

reflect.text: It must all sound so trivial, given what you've been through. Complaining about curtains while you... I didn't mean to whine. I'm sorry.

acknowledge.text: I was in this fluorescent-lit room, and the judge refused to make eye contact. He spoke in a monotone voice for 10 minutes, signed the papers, and it was over.
You've survived a lot. You could survive a divorce. You're made of tougher stuff than me. And you're what, twelve?

clarify.text: He asked me what I learned. I didn't learn anything. I already knew I wasn't supposed to... do the things I did. Maybe I learned not to do them again. But it's too late now.

reflect.text: It's over. Yes. Over. I'm staying at the Jolly Roger motel. It's habitable. The shower has good pressure. Small victories.

wait.text: When we walked out, my ex-wife turned to me and said, 'I wish things could have been different.' Not 'I wish you'd been different.' Things. Like it just happened to us.

clarify.text: When I woke up last Tuesday, there were three Post-it notes on the kitchen counter in handwriting that definitely wasn't mine - or hers. Something about yogurt brand preferences.

wait.text: Another man has been in my house. Eating yogurt. Leaving notes about his preferences. In my kitchen.

acknowledge.text: You're a clever one. That's exactly right. It's definitive proof of infidelity. Post-it notes. The mundane has become evidence.

reflect.text: I have a lactose sensitivity. I don't eat yogurt. Never have. She knows this. The yogurt was never for me.

clarify.text: A Post-it note is like a... well, it's a small piece of paper with adhesive on the back. With words on the front. Words from the pen of another man.

reflect.text: I have been giving her compliments. Every single day. I prided myself on it. Relentless positivity.
Yes, such as: 'I prefer the shoestring fries. The wedges and the steak fries do nothing for me.' That's a compliment because it's honest feedback. She values my honesty.

acknowledge.text: I am relentlessly positive. It makes her uncomfortable, apparently. The therapist said I was 'aggressively nice.' I suppose the writing has been on the wall for some time now.

wait.text: The silence between us grew like a living thing. Eventually it was the only thing in the room. I just don't see the need for 'counseling' when everything is going just fine.

clarify.text: My father taught me about compliments. A compliment is 'when you look someone in the eye and tell them something that they need to hear.' That's exactly what he told me. Word for word.

exhausted_response: Have you seen my ex-wife? She hasn't changed those curtains yet... Wait, no, she has. I told you that already, didn't I?
author: Claude
